historical_significance: was so peaceful and amazing all at the same time worth a visit, for a tour and culture and traditions and seeing the baboo's
guide_quality: we had a guide that was very helpful and friendly and at a good price
staff were not pushy at all and were friendly
the monkeys aren't very friendly
cultural_value: africa at its finest, the "national zoo of gambia," a few hyenas and baboons—you shouldn't expect anything more, but this is a unique experience
our wise local guide pointed out three types of cattle, from sénégal, mali, and the gambia
a beautiful and well-maintained forest where you can spot birds with a local guide
ferry_service: what follows is in essence a very nice walk following a well worn path through shady and peaceful woodland, a few birds along the way but nothing you won't see around your hotel, an army of ants crossing the path, some epic spider's webs, but not much else

i only gave two stars because the forest itself is quite nice to walk around and i came with low expectations but i had the opportunity of taking a day trip from one of the beach resorts earlier in my holiday and i'm really glad i didn't

hotel needs a little tlc , but look pass that and u would have a wonderful holiday , staff were so friendly and we had a laugh with lot of them , and went out with one of the staff for the day , good ok , pool kept nice and clean by ( chicken legs ha ha ) he was a great laugh, pa for fishing trip (great day out ) and well pa in side bar he crazy and so much fun ,ok to go to town the boy do wait out side hotel but you can just say no thank you , we didn't and they carry yr shopping and tell u about the town ( all they ask is a english pound , that's cheap to learn a lot
infrastructure_state: it's a shame to see the hyenas in their cage in poor condition
never seen animals is such appalling conditions, no clean water, hyenas that were so mange ridden it must of been awful for them in the heat
the hyenas weren't in good condition either
accessibility_comfort: our guide was nice enough but basically it's a long walk down a path through bushes

then more walking until finally you get to the world's most depressing zoo - where they'll tell you some thoroughly unconvincing nonsense about why these baboons needed to be in an enclosure rather than just free
after this it was a boiling hot walk through a sandy path with more nonsensical waffling from the smelly guide
value_pricing: a waste of time and money
two birds in the distance - use the expensive binoculars
at this time, it's definitely not worth visiting the reserve
safety_security: apparently it is too “dangerous” to go without a guide
if you don't know where to look, very dangerous'
they do look dangerous but we had a ranger protecting us while we take our picture with them having behind us in the close proximity

general_improvements: The animals' living conditions are terrible
Was so disappointed with this place
We were a bit disappointed; perhaps we were there at the wrong time
We had no interest in visiting the "zoo" preferring to spend our time looking for birds and we were not disappointed
We had previously visited other reserves in Gambia and this one disappointed us
The 'protected' forest itself is very disappointing and most of the animals have left, bar a few monkeys
Many people have commented on how awful they find the animals in cages, but it's not much different from a zoo in our home country
It's a shame to see the hyenas in their cage in poor condition

For many years ago it was a nice place where they had names on evert special trees and there were so many different animals there, but now I'm disappointed because it's mostly apes and births there now day
Never seen animals is such appalling conditions, no clean water, Hyenas that were so mange ridden it must of been awful for them in the heat
Our guide was great and very informative but the lack of animals was disappointing and I'm sure we walked a couple of hours
The Hyenas were in an awful state, one was surrounded by vultures and it was obvious he was sick
We went late morning and were disappointed: little to see, some caged hyenas, self appointed guide, aggressive monkeys (not like Bijolo)

Was a terrible day out, it would be a bit better if they cleared all the wood carving sellers away - or only let one or two sell - not around 10 that you have to pass on your way out, all selling the same things
We were actually a bit disappointed with this park
I may have ideas as to how this could be improved and would love to be able to help in someway
We were sorry we didn't see crocs from the lookout point across the pool, and were disappointed and saddened by the dirty-looking 'animal orphanage' - even if they did have hyenas and pelicans
The one bad point is the awful 'zoo' in the middle where they house baboons, hyenas and turtles
We saw very little and were very disappointed
The hyenas were pacing up and down ie exhibiting stereotypical behavior, which was not good to see at all

guide_quality: my husband and i stopped here on our way to george town we got to talk to the most knowledgeable man ever the stone man he really knows his stuff and explained everything to you and things start to add up once he starts to explain it all to you , as myself and my husband are into spiritaul things we just couldn’t get enough of the place
it is 1,000% safe, the people are lovely and friendly
cultural_value: due to local beliefs and respect the other circles have not been excavated
in the middle of no-where, in a country where electricity is a luxury, that was a very special treat
stunning special place
safety_security: it is 1,000% safe, the people are lovely and friendly

guide_quality: excellent english is spoken, which is helpful for negotiating
the people are generally friendly
however, one should not be afraid of direct contact with the always friendly vendors and should not be afraid of the sometimes narrow alleys between the stalls
cultural_value: nothing special to see if you have been to similar markets and a hassle when “guides” won’t leave you alone
you cannot take photos of locals unless you buy from them
didn’t buy  much but  nice to see locals selling their food
ferry_service: he was very good at adjusting the trip after our needs
accessibility_comfort: i felt very comfortable walking around with someone who was familiar with the do's and don'ts of the market, so i was very happy to have a guide
and tell us that you can handle it better and be more comfortable with it because you are more than happy with your religion
it’s best to go with a guide or someone that knows the place as it’s easy to get lost in the winding alleys and narrow ways
value_pricing: nothing to see except locals buying cheap chinese rubbish and food
souvenirs were a bit more expensive than the bakau craft market
it was a really busy market selling everything but it's worth it more for the experience than to buy stuff
safety_security: it's safe, no one will bother you
it is not safe to go alone as you get too much hassle and pick picketers
guidelines regarding hygiene and food safety, as we know them, will likely be unfamiliar here

general_improvements: Grit your teeth, ignore the bumsters, and go your own way, and you won't be disappointed
Most of what is on sale is poor quality Chinese produce

guide_quality: it is a little difficult to just browse here as all the sellers call out for you to visit their 'shop', however the atmosphere is friendly
the people are extremely friendly and kind

birds and animals we saw hippos and crocodiles and a huge variety of bird-life along small backwaters that make the gambia so attractive to bird-watchers abdoulie was an excellent guide with a wealth of local knowledge and contacts which made the trip run smoothly and tailored to what we wanted to see we never felt we were being herded along on a package tour
cultural_value: here you'll find wood and stone statues, as well as hand-carved traditional masks, at very reasonable prices
well worth a visit to see local carvers at work and displaying their item for sale if you see something you like always haggle and you will get it for somewhere half the asking price
this craft market at the border of the senegambia is one of many in gambia and displays a wide variety of hand made local products
ferry_service: our trip took in the wassu stone circles (evidence of ancient civilization here); the wonderful janjanbureh camp with its perfect location on the river gambia and good quality accommodation and food; the historic towns of janjanbureh and kuntaur, the bustling 'crossroad' town of farafenni, the riverside tendaba camp and the rural villages along the country's south road

birds and animals we saw hippos and crocodiles and a huge variety of bird-life along small backwaters that make the gambia so attractive to bird-watchers abdoulie was an excellent guide with a wealth of local knowledge and contacts which made the trip run smoothly and tailored to what we wanted to see we never felt we were being herded along on a package tour
accessibility_comfort: it is a little difficult to just browse here as all the sellers call out for you to visit their 'shop', however the atmosphere is friendly
value_pricing: bargaining is key, but try to squeeze through to the back (happy corner) for less pushiness and fair prices
keep in mind that you should bargain, but don't go overboard, as they think it's a big price, and a difference of a few euros might not be too much for you
here you'll find wood and stone statues, as well as hand-carved traditional masks, at very reasonable prices
safety_security: a real experience the trip was a mind-altering experience into the way of life of a country with wonderful people and beautiful scenery in which the hospitality was outstanding and where we felt welcome and safe at all times

quotes: it is a little difficult to just browse here as all the sellers call out for you to visit their 'shop', however the atmosphere is friendly

historical_significance: this small museum gives a fascinating insight into the gambian way of life and its traditions

off the tour visit for sometime but worth going in a taxi, 200d each to go in very informative and lots of live craft to watch done in the traditional way, we have not been for some time and it has improved, would not visit every year but would return in future
guide_quality: our guide was very knowledgeable and i came a way with a real insight into traditional gambian village life

i also watched a weaver busy with his craft and listened to traditional songs played by a band of musicians while sitting in the bantaba sipping tea and trying to appease my customary curiosity by firing unending questions at the knowledgeable guide
the guides are knowledgeable and informative
cultural_value: i had a guide named tamba jefang from finfoot birding, which was a unique experience
it would be nice if there were regular, lively cultural events, such as traditional festivals with music and dance, and other things that go with it
you'll be amazed at how the people here still do everything traditionally
ferry_service: the museum offers a nice introduction to gambian life but, having just returned from a 4-day trip along the river gambia with tour company "tour gambia" (100% recommended), we felt we knew a lot of what was told us and/or had already seen many of the exhibits in a more natural setting - ie in a real village, or had seen the wildlife or birds along the river or mangrove backwaters
hundreds, even thousands, of residents gather on a good 200 meters of beach to empty a dozen primitive fishing boats
accessibility_comfort: they were comfortable
don't expect a fancy place like one of the hotels in the touristic areas, but you have everything you need, like flushing toilet, comfortable bed, shower, etc
the tanji village museum is located on the main road and is easy to find
value_pricing: prices in the shop were genuine and good value
the cost was very reasonable at d150 for adults and d25 for children

good demostrations and our tour guide was informative and friendly i think the wildlife section could be updated and the old huts where the head of the villiage and the families lived could do with a repaint otherwise i enjoyed my visit to this museum located to the south of tanji on the main highway traditional african drums and other instruments are played and you can sit in the bar to listen to the african music and partake in light refreshments at reasonable prices

general_improvements: It got extremely crowded (but not as pungently awful as the smoking area)
The smell was awful but made the visit

historical_significance: the history and legend are definitely worth taking in, and perhaps you'll change your perspective
the history of this sacred pool is very interesting and being so close to the crocodiles is an amazing experience
what an amazing experience from when you arrive to see the interesting museum with local instruments and the history of the gambia, then on to the crocodile pool
guide_quality: amazing time, our guide keba was very kind and helpful at getting us to all of our destinations
ali is a very friendly man
the pool guides are knowledgeable and friendly
cultural_value: they do ask for a donation to "feed" the crocodiles and some locals selling pencils and books for the local children
we walked from cape point (approx 20 minutes) with very little hassle so had the added bonus of seeing where the locals live
if you are in the area you should make the visit and from further afield it would be worth negotiating a price with a local taxi driver
ferry_service: a good local trip and interesting museum that explains a great deal of the gambian history

with a historical museum to walk through, educating us of gambian soldiers who fought in the world war and local traditional practices, and much more was a nice informative way to start of a great trip
off the beaten track and through a very poor area in bakou, you get to see a more real side of gambia on your journey there
accessibility_comfort: never believed i could be comfortable walking amongst a bunch of very large crocodiles, and even petting one, but i was

our hotel,but it did mean a walk through bakau old town which is a poverty striking area with lots of kids begging for sweets, so i was glad we hired a guy from the beach to take us there, as his presence made the journey there very easy

there is a well trodden path, through some huge trees and local monkeys until you hit the pool, where rangers will arrange for visitors to pose with and touch the crocs for some great photo opportunities
value_pricing: and at 100 dalsi spot, it's cheap
we called in here on the way back to our hotel and it was definitely worth it
d100 entry fee was reasonable and they may ask for a donation at the end which is completely up to you if you want to give some
safety_security: living in florida, i know to keep a safe distance form alligators
very knowledgeable guides ensure your visit is safe
they tell you where to walk to stay safe

general_improvements: There is a small museum at the entrance, very small park, we came out disappointed
Was kind if disappointing so short but, worth it
Touching a crocodile has to be a bucket list things to do & we were not disappointed
Anyway they enjoyed the experience, pool men could be better informed and interactive in the job role
Wasn't disappointed, there's looots of them in a small pool, lying around everywhere, calm and lazy just lounging
The road are terrible and if you have to walk you realize you walking along open sewer

historical_significance: these precious, valuable historical items are not well-protected and exposed to air and people touching them,  the items merit a financial investment to upgrade how the items are conserved
guide_quality: our tour guides were very knowledgeable regarding the artifacts in the museum
but if you take a taxi, the driver can also give you excellent explanations
the only employee was friendly and helpful
cultural_value: here, with respect for the history of the country and its people, and with modest resources, a place has been created that uniquely illuminates the harsh aspects of life in an african country (then and now)
when in banjul, take a look into this small but fairly well organized museum over gambian history and a glimpse of the local culture
a lovely museum, especially worth a visit if you're in banjul
infrastructure_state: no flashy building on independence drive in banjul, no slick presentations with all sorts of modern, possibly digital, gadgets, but very basic—that's how the national museum's accommodation and layout can be characterized
the museum artifacts are not kept in good condition
accessibility_comfort: restroom is in another building, not wheel chair accessible
safety_security: located in an old colonial building it is home to historical documents and displays concerning the gambia

quotes: located in an old colonial building it is home to historical documents and displays concerning the gambia

historical_significance: it isn't that beautiful but it has a bloody history that will tell you about the dictator and the killings going on in front of the arch
nice to see and definitely worth climbing, because from above you can clearly see that gambia is an island, halfway up the arch there is a small room decorated with historical items
guide_quality: for 50 dalasi, you get a tour of the arch all the way to the top, and an excellent view of banjul
the guides take great care of you and are very informative
they were informative, we enjoyed their company so much that we asked for the same guides again
cultural_value: entrance is 100 dalasis for foreigners, a few steps, then a beautiful view, and above all, it's a gathering place for locals
leggendo le guide pensi che sia qualcosa di importante da vedere, però quando ci arrivi, ti accorgi che non è niente di speciale
it is very much a local landmark
ferry_service: the view over banjul was brill, entrance fee was very cheap less than 50p theres a small museum inside which is interesting, and when you come down across the road is billys bar where they sell good cold cheap drinks service with a smile
infrastructure_state: the condition is shockingly poor, and while there are a few rooms to look at, they're without light, very neglected, and everything is falling apart
the building is in a sorry state, and the elevator is broken, so it's not really worth seeing for people with disabilities; you have to climb the stairs
it's in poor condition anyway, and i would advise against visiting it due to the risk of accidents (elevator shaft open, etc
accessibility_comfort: access to the upper floors can be made through a series of several marble spiral stairs
we stopped here on our visit to banjul and it is easy to park nearby, there are eating and drinking facilities nearby so we stopped and took some photo's
this is an easy tourist attraction to visit and it is also nice if you want to take your own picnic, plenty of space
value_pricing: not worth a visit if it weren't for the view; a quick stop, and that's enough; it's a shame they don't take care of it a bit
it's not worth going there just for the arch; you can easily see it as part of a city tour
not worth looking at it
safety_security: unfortunately it’s not been well looked after and maintained- the elevator doesn’t work and the stairway is really dark which is dangerous because it’s a winding, loopy staircase

historical_significance: it was amazing to learn about the history and significance of the structure itself as well as the history, language and culture of the gambian north bank
halima, the excellent tour guide, provided us with a fascinating insight into how the fort operated; its role in the abolition of slavery and the wider historical context
a well done museum  with ghoulish artifacts but a wonderful history of the terrible slave trade presented by a very enthusiastic curator who showed us around
guide_quality: the museum here is just as good as the main national one in banjul, and because there are so few visitors, you get your own guided tour from the very knowledgeable curator who works there
the museum guide was particularly helpful and explained the history of the place in detail
the guide was informative and worth having
cultural_value: a local guide explains the details
just up the beach from fort bullen, a local educator is putting together a black cultural archive
accessibility_comfort: easily accessible and hugely enlightening
i am based in fajara, and it was easy to catch a couple of bush taxis, get the ferry and the walk to the fort from the ferry terminal in barra
the fort is easy to find, has a convenient parking and nice scenic views

general_improvements: This place should be better known
A well done museum  with ghoulish artifacts but a wonderful history of the terrible slave trade presented by a very enthusiastic curator who showed us around

guide_quality: very friendly people selling their wares
while all the traders were extremely friendly and eager for us to buy, none of them were aggressively pushy and all of them kept smiling even when we didn't buy from their stalls
the stall holders are friendly and in most cases low pressure, just come and look
cultural_value: local to ngala lodge hotel, the goods here seem to be of a better quality than some of the other markets
love all the colourful costumes the local women wear
locals a bit too pushy with tourists just be firm and walk away
accessibility_comfort: it was interesting and easy to walk around with very little hassle
value_pricing: worth seeing, but quite expensive
a little haggling is recommended, but when something is already so cheap, i have a hard time doing so and don't go overboard
not some cheap chinese reproduction
safety_security: this safe, relaxed and authentic market offers value for money and some terrific souvenirs

historical_significance: batik fabrics, with their intricate patterns and vibrant colors, added a touch of vibrancy to the market, while traditional clothing offered a fascinating glimpse into local culture
perhaps you will even catch some djembe players in action or just buy one of these beautifully made traditional drums to take home
guide_quality: offer a 1/3 and meet in the middle unless you're very generous and pay their inflated price all good fun and they certainly won't sell at a loss they're great vendors, chatty, friendly and interested in where you're from
badou and tapha jewelleries are very friendly men with beautiful, reasonably priced jewelry

everyone was very friendly and just wanted you to buy from them, i laughed and explained to one lady i didn't have enough money to spend on every stall, she laughed to so a polite no thank you and i'm all spent up was enough for them to stop, but we never really felt like it was a shark frenzy we thought everyone was very friendly, and would happily go again again for an hour or two
cultural_value: this market has lots of decent local craft items but the problem is some of the stall holders are so pushy it wears you down, even experienced travellers avoid it

very interesting to see arts and crafts batik in senegambia craft market for the best local guide to show you around please kindly contact +220 7647423 

thank you for your kindly attention
a great little market for authentic african souvenirs (bags, keychains, statues, paintings, jewelry)
ferry_service: nice wood carving market where you can buy all sorts of things, also various clothes at good prices, easy to find at the beginning of the strip
nice little market with jewary bags that kind of stuff just off the strip very busy so keep an eye on you bags nice people
near the top of the strip, the craft market seems to be stocked with imported goods than locally crafted ones, and most of the stalls looked very similar
accessibility_comfort: be sure to enter with some self-control, because it’s easy to want to buy every single thing you see

i was shouted at by one store owner as i was effecting his business i know thus is a difficult time for gambians but found it very hostile and some if them very angry and aggressive i certainly wont be visiting again

wife bought usual wooden carving and stuff for presents to take home (or tat as i call it)   
easy to find at crossroads on the strip
value_pricing: cheap nic naks in small stalls found at the top end of the strip
go early before all the stalls are set up and you will find things much cheaper than inside the hotels themselves
the only difference is that they are more expensive as this market is for tourists

general_improvements: We met a guy in a bar one night who said he could make carvings of our pets, so I asked if I could see his work and it was spot on, we agreed a price I messaged a photos of the dogs and paid a deposit, he issued a receipt with phone number and all info, if you want anything like this go to unit 12, you will not be disappointed
Many of the carvings are of a poor quality and they are liable to split when brought home
This is a very small craft market in the strip, where you can buy some souvenirs and you don't have to suffer the terrible smell of bigger markets such as the one in Banjul

historical_significance: however, hearing the history definitely makes it an important and worthwhile visit
a beautiful place with a terribly sad history
a fascinating day trip around the island learning about the slave trade and past history
guide_quality: he also always has cold drinks (water and soft drinks) for you, which was very helpful considering the temperatures
he was very knowledgeable and answered all of my questions
our guide abdul was so insightful and knowledgeable
cultural_value: we visited this with our local driver and guide, muhammed camara (also known as big mo)
during this excursion, i heard the true story from the tour guide and a local historian
with a local tour guard
ferry_service: took a taxi from there for a 30 minute ride to a beautiful fishing village, and from there took a nice boat ride to kunta kinteh island, which is a very tiny island
the ferry is inconsistent and isn't in the best of shape
however, a word of warning, the journey to get there is long (took us 10 hours there and back through there was a problem with the ferry so might be 8 on a good day)
infrastructure_state: as another review said - i do wish they would keep up with it more if possible, as it's likely to be gone one day in the not-so-distant future due to decay (per our guide, even)

the government really ought to put some money into the more popular visitors sites, the slavery museum and its exhibits were of poor quality and kunta kinteh island could do with a complete makeover before it suffers from further decay
accessibility_comfort: big mo is highly recommended if you're looking for a reliable, english-speaking guide who's easy to work with and arranges everything perfectly for you
value_pricing: the trip was cheaper, the group smaller (we didn't lose an hour picking up from various other hotels) and the transport was in a mix of pick-up trucks and jeeps, as well as the ferry to the north and the small boat to the island
the journey from kololi to kunta kinteh is a long one, but well worth it to learn more about the appalling trade in human lives that was carried out
i expect we were overcharged and while it's a good place to visit, and the ferry and pirogue were also good experiences, i don't think it was worth it in terms of the cost and time traveling
safety_security: after this, i can safely say that what we did was wrong, but we are not the main culprits
